update.description:
Previously, if no Optitrack was connected, the Optitrack receiver thread started by HaptixControlPlugin would block continuously. This caused a segfault whenever ServerFixture unloaded a world containing HaptixControlPlugin.

This pull request implements polling in the Optitrack receiver so that it knows when to exit the packet reception loop. It also fixes a bug in the construction of the Optitrack thread in HaptixControlPlugin that was causing the thread to make its own copy of the Optitrack object.

Lots of help from @caguero on this one, thanks!

branch of [PR 107](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/107/include-serverfixture), please review 107 first.

~~You will need Gazebo [PR 1588](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1588/1569-fix-crash-in-hydraplugin/diff) in order to run the example test without crashing in the HydraPlugin destructor.~~ merged
update.title: Poll instead of blocking in Optitrack receiver

content.raw: I'm fine with `std::atomic<bool>`. We just have to modify the way we read it (`load()`) and the way we write it (`store()`).
content.html: I'm fine with std::atomic<bool>. We just have to modify the way we read it (load()) and the way we write it (store()).

pull_request.title: Poll instead of blocking in Optitrack receiver

pullrequest.title: Poll instead of blocking in Optitrack receiver

content.raw:
You can make the bool atomic using `std::atomic<bool>`. Which would be fine in this case, and you could get ride of the mutex.

The ultimate question is, what is affect of reading a true even if the bool is being set to false? In this case, there doesn't seem to be any negative consequences (but maybe you found such a case).
content.html:
You can make the bool atomic using std::atomic<bool>. Which would be fine in this case, and you could get ride of the mutex.

The ultimate question is, what is affect of reading a true even if the bool is being set to false? In this case, there doesn't seem to be any negative consequences (but maybe you found such a case).

pull_request.title: Poll instead of blocking in Optitrack receiver

pullrequest.title: Poll instead of blocking in Optitrack receiver

content.raw: I think it's needed because we're using `this->active` for checking when to finish. A different thread can call `this->stop()` with a potential race condition reading/writing `this->active`. @nkoenig , do you think is not needed?
content.html: I think it's needed because we're using this->active for checking when to finish. A different thread can call this->stop() with a potential race condition reading/writing this->active. @nkoenig , do you think is not needed?

content.raw: Do you think the `activeMutex` mutex is needed at all? It only exists to protect a boolean, and setting a boolean is an atomic action, correct?
content.html: Do you think the activeMutex mutex is needed at all? It only exists to protect a boolean, and setting a boolean is an atomic action, correct?

update.description:
Previously, if no Optitrack was connected, the Optitrack receiver thread started by HaptixControlPlugin would block continuously. This caused a segfault whenever ServerFixture unloaded a world containing HaptixControlPlugin.

This pull request implements polling in the Optitrack receiver so that it knows when to exit the packet reception loop. It also fixes a bug in the construction of the Optitrack thread in HaptixControlPlugin that was causing the thread to make its own copy of the Optitrack object.

Lots of help from @caguero on this one, thanks!

branch of [PR 107](#!/osrf/handsim/pull-request/107/include-serverfixture), please review 107 first.

~~You will need Gazebo [PR 1588](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1588/1569-fix-crash-in-hydraplugin/diff) in order to run the example test without crashing in the HydraPlugin destructor.~~ merged

content.raw:
Do we need this? It generates a warning:

```
#!c++
cc1: warning: command line option ‘-std=c++11’ is valid for C++/ObjC++ but not for C [enabled by default]
```

Probably because we're compiling `polhemus_driver` that is C code.
content.html:
Do we need this? It generates a warning:

cc1: warning: command line option ‘-std=c++11’ is valid for C++/ObjC++ but not for C [enabled by default]

Probably because we're compiling polhemus_driver that is C code.
